conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves forward.
There are four objects: yellowish object, camera/device, small lump/object, and peach/fruit.
Each object casts a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The light source is positioned above and behind the view causing shadows to appear in front of objects.
All shadows will shift backward when the light source moves forward.
The point where light rays hit the ground will move further behind each object.
Shadows will move in the opposite direction of the light source's movement.
All shadows will become shorter when the light source moves closer.
The angle of the light rays becomes steeper as the light source gets closer.
Closer light sources create shadows with sharper edges.
The umbra becomes more prominent than the penumbra.
Shadow A will move backward, become shorter, and may become slightly wider.
Shadow B will move backward, become shorter, and details will become more defined.
Shadow C will move backward, become notably shorter, and may show more detailed contours.
Shadow D will move backward, become shorter, and the rounded shape will become more pronounced.
All shadows will shift backward and become shorter with sharper edges when the light source moves forward.
